properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values are reaching -40 this morning. Extreme cold will return again Tuesday evening over this area. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight. A low pressure system from Texas will bring a total snowfall amount of 10 to 15 cm tonight. Gusty southerly winds may cause occasional blowing snow in exposed areas this evening. The snow will taper to a few flurries Tuesday morning as the low moves across Lake Huron and Georgian Bay into Quebec. Poor winter driving conditions are expected. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. The snowfall warning criterion of 15 cm in a 12 hour period is not expected to be reached. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-18T13:09:42-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow with accumulations potentially reaching 10 to 15 cm is expected from Tuesday to Wednesday. A Colorado low will bring snow to several regions of Quebec on Tuesday. Snow will begin in the morning over western parts of the province and will spread toward central and eastern regions during the day. Consider changing any non-essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowstorm beginning this evening. A low pressure system emerging from Texas is tracking towards the Great Lakes today. This low will bring an area of snow with it, arriving early this evening in the Sault Ste. Marie area then quickly spreading east to remaining regions north of Lake Huron and Georgian Bay by midnight. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected by the time the snow moves out of the area Tuesday morning. Driving conditions will quickly deteriorate after the snow arrives this evening. Motorists should be prepared to adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-18T09:41:09-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow with total accumulations of 15 centimetres is expected. Snow will develop Tuesday morning and will persist into the evening. A low pressure system developing over Colorado will track across Quebec on Tuesday and Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Moderate northwest winds combined with temperatures dipping near -40 tonight will give wind chill values near -58 overnight through Tuesday morning for parts of the Kivalliq. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain, and strong southerly winds expected on Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts (all of Newfoundland): 5 to 10 cm with some pockets of up to 15 cm possible. Total rainfall amounts (southern and eastern Newfoundland only): 15 to 25 mm, possibly higher over the Burin and southern Avalon Peninsulas. Maximum wind gusts: southerly generally between 60 to 80 km/h except 100 to 120 km/h across parts of western, southern, and eastern Newfoundland. Locations of only snow (no changeover to rain): western and northern Newfoundland. Locations of snow changing to rain: southern, eastern, and most of central Newfoundland. Time span: early Wednesday morning until Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow will develop over southwestern Newfoundland before dawn on Wednesday and spread across the Island Wednesday morning. Strong southerly winds will accompany the snow causing a few hours of poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow over all areas on Wednesday morning. The snow will change to rain over southern, eastern, and most of central Newfoundland. The precipitation will taper off over western Newfoundland Wednesday afternoon and over eastern Newfoundland Wednesday evening. The public should prepare for poor travel conditions on Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-18T11:17:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-17T19:18:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1487551431.2020

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for overnight and Tuesday. A band of snow will move over Eastern Ontario starting after 2 AM. Snow will continue well into Tuesday morning with total amounts of 5 to 10 cm expected by Tuesday afternoon. Locally higher amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible in a few localities just north of Lake Ontario. Poor winter driving conditions from accumulating snow and low visibility in briefly heavier snow are likely by Tuesday morning. The morning commute will be affected. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. Snow will change over to rain or drizzle Tuesday afternoon as a warm front moves through and temperatures rise above the zero degree mark. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-18T12:17:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-17T20:18:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1703130827.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow on the way beginning this evening into tonight. A low pressure system will emerge from Texas and track towards the Great Lakes today. This low will bring an area of snow with it, arriving this evening near the shores of Lake Superior or tonight north of Lake Huron. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm will be possible by the time the snow moves out of the area Tuesday morning. Snowfall warnings may be required. There is some uncertainty as to the exact track of the low, which will affect how much snow falls at a particular location. Poor winter driving conditions are expected beginning this evening. Motorists should be prepared to adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Snow on the way beginning tonight into Tuesday morning. A low pressure system will emerge from Texas and track towards the Great Lakes today. This system will bring an area of snow with it, arriving tonight east of Georgian Bay. The snow will arrive Tuesday morning near and east of the National Capital region. Total snowfall amounts near 10 cm appear likely in most areas, with locally higher amounts up to 15 cm possible in the Ottawa Valley by the time the snow moves out of the area Tuesday evening. There is some uncertainty as to the exact track of the low, which will affect how much snow falls at a particular location. Poor winter driving conditions from accumulating snow and low visibility in areas of heavier snow are expected beginning tonight.
